children.name: linux.html
children.title: 4. Linux
children.content: 4. Linux # 4. Linux Security Audit Linux is the only mainstream operating system that grants users complete architectural control. Every line of kernel code is auditable. Every service can be disabled. Every packet can be inspected. This transparency enables verifiable security but demands technical competence. children.title: 3. MacOS
children.content: 3. MacOS # 3. MacOS Security Audit MacOS occupies the middle ground between Windows surveillance and Linux freedom. Apple builds competent security architecture but wraps it in proprietary control systems that restrict user agency. The platform excels at protecting you from external threats while simultaneously tracking your behavior for Apple's benefit. This audit examines both sides of that trade-off. You should understand threat modeling, practice good digital hygiene, and have hardened your operating system before implementing network-level defenses. What is a VPN? A Virtual Private Network (VPN) creates an encrypted tunnel between your device and a remote server. children.content: #2. Tor Network & Anonymity Prerequisites Complete Part 1 (VPN Configuration) before this guide. Understanding VPN limitations is essential for knowing when to use Tor. This guide assumes you have a hardened operating system and practice good operational security. What is Tor? The Onion Router (Tor) is an anonymity network that routes traffic through multiple encrypted relays, making it extremely difficult to link you to your destination. children.name: part7.html
children.title: 7. DNS Security & Privacy
children.content: # 7. DNS Security & Privacy Why DNS Security Matters Every website you visit, every API call your applications make, every email you send—all of it starts with a DNS query. Your ISP sees every domain you resolve. Governments log DNS queries for surveillance. Attackers use DNS tunneling for command-and-control. children.name: part8.html
children.title: 8. Traffic Analysis & D.P.I
children.content: # 8. Traffic Analysis & D.P.I Why Traffic Analysis Matters Modern networks are encrypted, but encryption hides content—not behavior. Traffic analysis reveals what applications are running, when users are active, what sites they visit, and whether malware is calling home. You cannot defend what you cannot see. children.title: 9. Wireless Security & Rogue AP
children.content: # 9. Wireless Security & Rogue AP Why Wireless Security Matters WiFi networks broadcast your data through walls to anyone within range. Weak encryption allows neighbors and attackers to intercept traffic. Rogue access points trick you into connecting, stealing credentials and monitoring communications.
